lines.text: Not that I care, but where is your husband?
Why, he's dead.
I bet he's just using that as an excuse.
I was with him to the very end.
No wonder he passed away.
I held him in my arms and kissed him.
Oh, I see, then it was murder. Will you marry me? Did he leave you any money? Answer the second question first.
He left me his entire fortune.
Is that so? Can't you see what I'm trying to tell you? I love you.
I got a good mind to join a club and beat you over the head with it.
Married. I can see you right now in the kitchen, bending over a hot stove. But I can't see the stove.
I didn't come here to be insulted!
That's what you think!
The Department of Labor wishes to note that the workers of Freedonia are demanding shorter hours.
Very well, we'll give them shorter hours. We'll start by cutting their lunch hour to 20 minutes.
We've been expecting you. As chairwoman of the reception committee, I extend the good wishes of every man, woman, and child of Freedonia.
Never mind that stuff.
[He takes out a deck of cards]
Take a card.

[as she takes one]
Card? What will I do with the card?
You can keep it. I've got fifty-one left. Now what were you saying?

he really is an idiot. I implore you, send him back to his father and brothers, who are waiting for him with open arms in the penitentiary. I suggest that we give him ten years in Leavenworth, or eleven years in Twelveworth.
I'll take five and ten in Woolworth.
Now I aska you one. What has a trunk, but no key, weighs 2,000 pounds and lives in a circus?
That's irrelevant.
Irrelephant? Hey, that'sa that answer. There's a whole lot of irrelephants in the circus.
Here is the Treasury Department's report, sir. I hope you'll find it clear.
Clear? Huh. Why a four-year-old child could understand this report.
[to Bob Roland]
Run out and find me a four-year-old child, I can't make head or tail of it.
Something must be done! War would mean a prohibitive increase in our taxes.
Hey, I got an uncle lives in Taxes.
No, I'm talking about taxes - money, dollars!
Dollars! There's-a where my uncle lives! Dollars, Taxes!
Take a letter.
Who to?
To my dentist.
[Roland writes out the following]
Uh... Dear dentist, enclosed find check for $500, yours very truly. Send that off immediately.
I'll, um, I'll have to enclose a check first.
You do and I'll fire you.
Remember, you're fighting for this woman's honor, which is probably more than she ever did.
Where's my Stradivarius?
Here, sir.
I'll show 'em they can't fiddle around with old Firefly!
[he pulls a tommygun out of his violin case and opens fire]
Look at 'em run! Now they know they've been in a war!
Your Excellency!
Hahahahahaha, they're fleeing like rats!
But sir, I've got to tell you...
Remind me to give myself the Firefly Medal for this!
[he fires again]
Your Excellency, you're shooting your own men!
[Firefly fires again]
What?
You're shooting your own men!
Here's $5, keep it under your hat.
[holds out his hat to take the $5 back]
Never mind, I'll keep it under my hat.
Go, and never darken my towels again!
I'll teach you to kick me!
You don't have to teach me, I know how!
[He kicks him]
Your Excellency! I thought you'd left.

[Impersonating Rufus T. Firefly]
Oh, no, I no leave.
But I saw you with my own eyes!
Well, who you gonna believe? Me or your own eyes?
You're a brave man. Go and break through the lines. And remember, while you're out there risking your life and limb through shot and shell, we'll be in be in here thinking what a sucker you are.
Message from the front, sir.
Oh, I'm sick of messages from the front. Don't we ever get a message from the side? - What is it?
General Smith reports a gas attack. He wants to know what to do.
Tell him to take a teaspoonful of bicarbonate baking soda and a half a glass of water.
I've sponsored your appointment because I feel you are the most able statesman in all Freedonia.

Well, that covers a lot of ground. Say, you cover a lot of ground yourself. You better beat it - I hear they're going to tear you down and put up an office building where you're standing. You can leave in a taxi. If you can't get a taxi, you can leave in a huff. If that's too soon, you can leave in a minute and a huff. You know, you haven't stopped talking since I came here? You must have been vaccinated with a phonograph needle.
And now, members of the cabinet...
[pounds gavel]
we'll take up old business.
I wish to discuss the tariff.
Sit down, that's new business. No old business? Very well...
[pounds gavel]
we'll take up new business.
Now, about that tariff...
Too late, that's old business already. Sit down.

[into radio]
Calling all nations. Calling all nations. This is Rufus T. This is Rufus T. Firefly coming to you through the courtesy of the enemy. We're in a mess folks, we're in a mess. Rush to Freedonia! Three men and one woman are trapped in a building! Send help at once! If you can't send help, send two more women!
[Pinky enters and raises three fingers]
Make it three more women!

[singing]
If any form of pleasure is exhibited, report to me and it will be prohibited! I'll put my foot down, so shall it be... this is the land of the free! The last man nearly ruined this place he didn't know what to do with it. If you think this country's bad off now, just wait till I get through with it! The country's taxes must be fixed, and I know what to do with it. If you think you're paying too much now, just wait till I get through with it!
Now, Chicolini, I want a full detailed report of your investigation.

he no show up. Wednesday he go to the ball game, but we fool him, we no show up. Thursday it was a double-header, nobody show up. Friday it rained all day, there was no ball game, so we stayed home, we listen to it over the radio.
I'm in a hurry! To the House of Representatives! Ride like fury! If you run out of gas, get ethyl. If Ethel runs out, get Mabel! Now step on it!
Now that you're Secretary of War, what kind of an army do you think we ought to have?
Well, I tell you what I think, I think we should have a standing army.
Why should we have a standing army?
Because then we save money on chairs.
Hey! Do you want to be a public nuisance?
Sure! How much does the job pay?
That sort of testimony we can eliminate.
Atsa fine. I'll take some.
You'll take what?
Eliminate. A nice, cold glass eliminate.
Awfully decent of you to drop in today. Do you realize our army is facing disastrous defeat? What do you intend to do about it?
I've done it already.
You've done what?
I've changed to the other side.
So you're on the other side, eh? Well, what are you doing over here?
Well, the food is better over here.
We've got to get rid of that man at once. Now I've got a plan. You say something to make him mad, and he'll strike you... and we'll force him to leave the country.
That's a swell plan... why couldn't you arrange for me to strike him?
Ambassador Trentino is a very sensitive man. Perhaps if you insult him. He's very easy to insult. Why, I said something to Vera Marcal in his presence once, and he slapped my face.
Why didn't Vera slap your face?
She did.
What'd you say to her?
[Roland whispers it in his ear. Firefly slaps his face]
You ought to be ashamed of yourself. Where'd you hear that story?
Why, you told it to me.
Oh yes, I remember. I should have slapped Mrs. Teasdale's face when she told it to me.
How would you like a job in the mint?
Mint? No, no, I no like a mint. Uh, what other flavor you got?
Maybe you can suggest something. As a matter of fact, you do suggest something. To me you suggest a baboon.
What?
I, uh, I'm sorry I said that; it isn't fair to the rest of the baboons.

[to Chicolini]
I wanted to get a writ of habeas corpus, but I should have gotten a-rid of you instead.
I'll see my lawyer about this as soon as he graduates from law school!
Notables from every country are gathered here in your honor. This is a gala day for you.
Well, a gal a day is enough for me. I don't think I could handle any more.
As chairman of the reception committee, I welcome you with open arms.
Is that so? How late do you stay open?
Just for that, you don't get the job I was going to give you.
What job?
Secretary of War.
All right, I take it.
Sold.
Don't look now, but there's one man too many in this room, and I think it's you.
I could dance with you until the cows come home. On second thought, I'd rather dance with the cows till you come home.
Have you been trailing Firefly?
Have we been trailing Firefly? Why, my partner, he's got a nose just like a bloodhound.
Oh really?
Yeah, and the rest of his face don't look so good either.

[to Trentino]
Now, how about lending this country twenty million dollars, you old skinflint?
Twenty million dollars is a lot of money. I'd have to take that up with my Minister of Finance.
Well, in the meantime, could you let me have twelve dollars until payday?
Twelve dollars?
Don't be scared, you'll get it back. I'll give you my personal note for ninety days. If it isn't paid by then, you can... keep the note.
But I asked you to dig up something I can use against Firefly. Did you bring me his record?
[Pinky hands him a gramophone record]
No, no!
[Trentino flings the record away like a clay pigeon skeet. Pinky takes out a rifle and blasts it out of the air. Chicolini rings a bell on the desk and awards Pinky a cigar]
And the boy gets a cigar!
You didn't shadow Firefly?
Oh, sure we shadow Firefly - we shadow him all day.
But what day was that?
Shadowday!
[laughs loudly]
That's-a some joke, eh, boss?
[Trentino buries his face in his hands]

Mister you no understand. Look, he's a spy and I'm a spy, he work-a for me. I want him to find out-a something, but he no find out what I wanna find out. Now how am I gonna find out what I wanna find out if he no find out what I gotta find out?

[to Chicolini]
Come on up here, I wanna scare the cabinet.
Chicolini, I need you badly right now. What'll you take to come back and work for me again?
I'll take a vacation.
Good, you're hired.
Chicolini, give me a number from one to ten.
Eleven.
Right!
Chicolini, when were you born?
I don't-a remember. I was just a little baby.
Isn't it true you tried to sell Freedonia's secret war code and plans?
Sure, I sold a code and two pair of plans.
[Firefly and Mrs. Teasdale hear music coming from downstairs]
What's that?
Sounds to me like mice.
Mice? Mice don't play music.
No? How about the old maestro?

Here are the plans of war. They're as valuable as your life. And that's putting them pretty cheap. Watch them like a cat watched her kittens. Have you ever had kittens? No, of course not, you're too busy running around playing bridge. Can't you see what I'm trying to tell you, I love you.
Have we met each other before, sir?
I don't think so. In fact, I'm not sure I'm seeing you now; it must be something I ate.
How about taking up the tax?
How 'bout taking up the carpet?
I still insist we must take up the tax.
He's right, you've gotta take up the tacks before you can take up the carpet.

[trying to decide if Chicolini, Firefly, Pinky, or Bob Roland will make a suicidal run into no-mans-land to get help]
One of us has got to go get word to General Cooper and his men. One of us has got to go and risk his life for his country!
Let's draw straws.

No! I gots an idea. We have a runspot to see who we choose to go. Okay, here we go. Rrrrrrringspot! One-sa, two-sa, zig-zag-zav, poptie, gimmega, tin-lie, tav, harem, scarem, moychan, tarem, tare, tore...
[realizes that he's about to land on himself]
I did it wrong. Wait, wait, wait... I start here! Rrrrrrringspot! One-sa, two-sa, zig-zag-zav, poptie, gimmega, tin-lie, tav, harem, scarem, moychan, tarem, tare, tore...
[realizes he's about to land on himself again]
That's a-no good too! Oh, I got it! Rrrringspot, BUCK!
[points to Pinky]
Good luck!
Oh, your Excellency!
You're not so bad yourself.

I'd be unworthy of the high trust that's been placed in me if I didn't do everything in my power to keep our beloved Freedonia in peace with the world. I'd be only too happy to meet with Ambassador Trentino, and offer him on behalf of my country the right hand of good fellowship. And I feel sure he will accept this gesture in the spirit of which it is offered. But suppose he doesn't. A fine thing that'll be. I hold out my hand and he refuses to accept. That'll add a lot to my prestige, won't it? Me, the head of a country, snubbed by a foreign ambassador. Who does he think he is, that he can come here, and make a sap of me in front of all my people? Think of it - I hold out my hand and that hyena refuses to accept. Why, the cheap four-flushing swine, he'll never get away with it I tell you, he'll never get away with it.
[Trentino enters]
So, you refuse to shake hands with me, eh?
[slaps Trentino with his glove]
Mrs. Teasdale, this is the last straw. There's no turning back now! This means war!
Then it's war! Then it's war! Gather the forces. Harness the horses. Then it's war!
Dig trenches, with our men being killed off like flies? There isn't time to dig trenches. We'll have to buy them ready made. Here, run out and get some trenches. Wait a minute, get 'em this high...
[gestures to his chin]
and our soldiers won't need any pants. Wait a minute, get 'em this high...
[gestures over his head]
and we won't need any soldiers!
Chicolini, your partner has deserted you but I'm still counting on you. There is a machine gun nest near Hill 28. I want it cleaned out.
All right, I'll tell the janitor.

[to Rufus T. Firefly]
Peanuts to you!

[after Pinky drives off without him for the third time]
This is the only way to travel.
I've said enough, I'm a man of few words.
Scram!

[with his head stuck in a vase]
The last time this happened to me I was crawling under a bed.

[sees Firefly giving water to the ailing Mrs. Teasdale]
Hey, careful with the water! It's the only water we got!
Well, it's the only woman we've got!
What can this mug offer you? Wealth and family? I can't give you wealth, but - uh - we can have a little family of our own!
Oh, Rufus!
All I can offer you is a roofus over your head.

Well, maybe I am a little headstrong. But, I come by it honestly. My father was a little headstrong. My mother was a little armstrong. The headstrongs married the armstrongs and that's why darkies were born.

[singing]
I will not stand for anything that's crooked or unfair. I'm strictly on the up-and-up, so everyone beware. If anyone's caught taking graft... and I don't get my share, we stand him up against the wall and...
[imitates firing a rifle]
Pop goes the weasel!
Lieutenant, why weren't the original indictment papers placed in my portfolio?
Why, uh, I didn't think those papers were important at this time, your excellency.
You didn't think they were important? Do you realize I had my dessert wrapped in those papers?
Oh, uh, I suppose you would think me a sentimental old fluff, but, uh, would you mind giving me lock of your hair?
A lock of my hair? Wh-why, I had no idea.
I was going to ask for the whole wig.
Well, you remember you gave us a picture of this man and said, 'Follow him?'
Oh, yes.
Well, we get on-a the job right away and in the one hour - even-a less than one hour...
Yes?
We lose-a the picture. That's-a pretty quick work, eh?

[locked in a bathroom]
Let me out of here! Hey, let me out of here or throw me a magazine!

[on the phone]
Get me headquarters. Not hindquarters, headquarters!
[Firefly emerges from a vase that has been stuck on his head]
Any mail for me while I was gone?
I'll see you at the opera tonight. I'll hold your seat till you get there. After you get there you're on your own.
Now, what is it that has four pairs of pants, lives in Philadelphia, and it never rains but it pours?
Atsa good one. I give you three guesses.
Now let me see. Has four pair of pants, lives in Philadelphia... Is it male or female?
No, I no think so.
Is he dead?
Who?
I don't know. I give up.
I give up, too.
I am willing to do anything to prevent this war.
It's too late. I've already paid a month's rent on the battlefield.
[answering the phone in Firefly's office]
Hello? No, not yet. All right, I tell him. Good-a-bye.
[He hangs up]
That was for you again.
I wonder whatever became of me? I should have been back here a long time ago.
Chicolini, you're charged with high treason, and if found guilty, you'll be shot.
I object.
You object? On what grounds?
I couldn't think of anything else to say.
Objection sustained.
Your Excellency, you sustain the objection?
Sure, I couldn't think of anything else to say either. Why don't you object?
Here, have a cigar.
[it's only a stub]
That's a good quarter cigar. I smoke the other 3/4 myself.
Your excellency, the ambassador's here on a friendly visit. He's had a change of heart.
he's still got the same face.
I'm sorry we lost our tempers; I'm willing to forgot if you are.

Forget? You ask me to forget? A Firefly never forgets. Why, my ancestors would rise from their graves, and I'd only have to bury them again. Nothing doing. I'm going back and clean the crackers out of my bed; I'm expecting company.
There goes my gun. Run out and get that like a good girl.
Now will you tell me what happened on Saturday?
I'm glad you ask me. We follow this man down to a roadhouse, and at this roadhouse he meet a married lady.
A married lady?
Yeah, I think it was his wife.
Firefly has no wife!
No?
No!
Then you know what I think, boss?
What?
I think-a we follow the wrong man.
This letter's the work of Trentino. The man is trying to undermine you. Now what are you going to do about it?
I've got a good mind to ring his doorbell and run.
Look at Chicolini. He sits there alone, an abject figure...

[immediately]
I abject!
Oh, for heaven's sake, whatever you do, don't make a sound! If you found, you lost!
Oh, you craze. How can I be lost if I'm found?
I danced before Napoleon. No, Napoleon danced before me. As a matter of fact, he danced 200 years before me.
Chicolini, I need you badly right now. What'll ya' take to come back and work for me again?
I'll take a vacation.
Good. You're hired!... Now, go out on that battlefield and lead those men to victory. Go on, they're waiting for you!
I wouldn't go out there unless I was in one of those big iron things, go up and down like this... What do you call-a those things?
Tanks.
You're welcome!

Send a messages out to all wires. The enemy has captured Hill 27 and 28 throwing 13 hillbillies out of work. Last night two snipers crept into our machine gun nest and laid an egg. Send reinforcements immediately. Send it on collect.
His Excellency's car!
His Excellency's car!
The future of Freedonia rest on you. Promise me you'll follow in the footsteps of my husband.

[Direct to the camera]
How do you like that? I haven't been on the job five minutes and already she's making advances to me.
Oh, I want to present to you Ambassador Trentino of Sylvania. Having him with us today is indeed a great pleasure.
Thank you, but I can't stay very long.
That's even a greater pleasure.
I want you to meet a very charming lady.
And it's about time!

The man doesn't live who can call a Firefly an upstart. Why, the Mayflower was full of Fireflys, and a few horseflies, too. The Fireflys were on the upper deck and the horseflies were on the Fireflys.
Why don't you marry me?
Why, marry you?
You take me and I'll take a vacation. I'll need a vacation if we're going to get married.
Rufus, what are you thinking of?
Oh, I was just thinking of all the years I wasted collecting stamps.
Oh, your Excellency, isn't there something I can do?
Yes, but I'll talk to you about that later.

[In walk trumpeters]
More bad news.
[In walks Mrs. Teasdale]
Didn't I tell ya.
Your Excellency.
What's on your mind, babe?
Freedonia's going to war!
I'm going to take a bath.
Chicolini, your partner's deserted us, but I'm still counting on you. There's a machine gun nest near Hill 28. I want it cleaned out.
Alright, I tell the janitor.
Any answer to that message?
No, sir.
Well, in that case, don't send it.
Remember, you're fighting for this woman's honor - which is probably more than she ever did.

[singing]
Hail! Hail Freedonia! Land of the Brave and Free!

[to Vera Marcal]
Here's one I picked up in a dance hall.
[Does a dance step]

[Designating Mrs. Teasdale]
Here's another one I picked up in a dance hall.

[Announcing arrival of dignitary at welcoming reception for Rufus T. Firefly]
The Honorable Secretary of Finance and Parties!"

[Secretary to Ambassador Trentino enters office, holding a telegram]
A telegram for you, Ambassador.

[Pinky grabs the telegram, glances at it, becomes very angry, tears the telegram up into small bits of paper and hurls them to the floor]
He gets mad because he can't read.

[singing, as he dances up to a woman who is standing with her back to a middle-aged man and talking to a handsome, younger man]
If any man should come between a husband and a bride. We find out which one she prefers by letting her decide. If she prefers the other one, the husband steps outside. We line him up against the wall and...
[imitates firing a rifle]
Pop goes the weasel!
I give all my time and energy to my duties, and what do I get?
You get awfully tiresome after a while!
Sir, you try my patience!
I don't mind if I do, you must try mine sometime!
That's the last straw, I resign! I wash my hands of the whole business!
Good idea, you can wash your neck, too!

[Pinky has been "responding" to questioning by Rufus T. Firefly by showing drawings on various parts of his body]
Well, I know one thing - I bet you haven't got a picture of my grandfather!

[Pinky nods vigorously in the affirmative, takes off his coat, pulls up his shirt and is about to pull down his trousers]
Uh uh, not now!
